chunks.en: Visas, Blank Passports, and Travel

Hello V friends, Happy Year of the Dragon!

I got my passport a few years ago, but I haven't actually used it.
Planning to travel abroad this year.
I did a quick search and only then discovered and learned about the concept of a "blank passport".
Is it necessary for ordinary people to appropriately 'brush' their entry and exit records to 'maintain' their passport?

If there's a chance, I still want to visit some developed regions (Western Europe, North America, New Zealand, etc.). Would having suitable entry and exit records make it easier to apply for the corresponding visas?
I don't feel it's necessary to deliberately 'brush' it, OP has many places he wants to go, and it would be even better if it could be done incidentally.
So I'm here to ask about the relationship between different visa policies and "blank passports".
- After entering and exiting with an e-visa, is it still a blank passport?
- After entering and exiting visa-free, is it still a blank passport?
- After entering and exiting with a visa on arrival, is it still a blank passport?

Thank you in advance, I won't reply to everyone individually.
Happy New Year!
You can also ask the customs officer to stamp the e-visa. The first developed country to visit is of course Singapore, visa-free.
Entry and exit stamps? It's already 2024, and many countries don't stamp passports anymore.
Even in China, they don't stamp at the self-service checkpoints.
They will stamp your passport upon entry and exit. At least your passport won't be completely blank.
No matter what visa you have, you need to get stamps on your passport with the entry and exit dates.
Unless you travel through Myanmar and Vietnam, you'll get a stamp whenever you enter or exit through any port of entry or exit.
After worshipping Mazu, going global directly, why bother with these trivial matters ğŸ˜„

@koto Thank you, does that mean that regardless of the visa policy (e-visa, visa on arrival, visa-free), they will stamp the passport? (I've never used my passport to exit the country before, covering my face)

chunks.en: @ladypxy What other V friends are saying seems a bit different from what you're saying... Generally speaking, if you don't mind the hassle, you can also choose the non-self-service channel, right? That way there's a record; otherwise, it's still a "blank passport". Is this understanding correct?
@abccba Don't worry, as a foreigner, you can't use the self-service channel to enter another country. Even with an e-visa, you have to go through manual processing.
@zxc12300123 Fun fact: many countries allow electronic passport holders to use self-service channels, regardless of nationality.
For example, you can scan your Chinese passport directly when entering Australia.

chunks.en: Building a travel history might be helpful for some regions, but when I applied for a Schengen tourist visa last time, despite having previously been to Japan and South Korea, and wanting to submit my old passport to aid the application, VFS said that I only needed to submit travel records from Schengen countries and didn't need to provide records from other regions.

Being a blank passport doesn't matter much. I had a blank passport when I applied for a US visa, and the consulate didn't care. Also, entry and exit aren't always stamped; different ports of entry in the same country may have different practices. Many US ports don't stamp passports anymore.
There's absolutely no need.

Many countries have switched to e-visas now, so there are no paper visas in the passport, and there are self-service channels for entry and exit. You won't get a stamp if you use the self-service channel.
@abccba @Neillou
Sorry, I accidentally touched it without turning the screen off.

They don't care about whether it is blank or not, they only care about whether you have money and whether you are coming to spend money. This applies to green cards and naturalization as well. The core issue they are concerned about is whether you have money and whether you can pay more taxes. The Five Eyes member states are all connected. Once you submit your phone number, passport number, address, and email, they know everything...
I got my US visa with a blank passport back then, and the non-blank passport of the person traveling with me was 'checked', so it doesn't really matter.
Visas can be sticker visas, separate-page visas (like in Southeast Asian countries), visas on arrival, or electronic visas, but you will always get a stamp on your passport when entering and exiting.
A regular passport is valid for 10 years, what's there to 'brush'? I've already changed 2 passports.
Just going there is more meaningful than having dozens of stamps.
"Got a passport a few years ago" Even if you're going to a visa-free region, it's best to check the passport's validity before you go. It's generally required to be valid for at least six months.
